description: Basic Cuban salsa step used in Rueda; dancers step slightly back and forward. Hands closest to middle of circle meet on the 5.
Fundamental cross-body lead in Cuban style; switches partners' orientation.
Basic inside turn where leader redirects follower through the center.
Two consecutive enchufla turns.
Leader presents the follower outward in a circular display turn.
Deli que no and leader leads follow in a left hand turn, leader steps to right and uses right arm to rotate follow around leader.
Step borrowed from Cuban Son footwork.
Often comes after Paso de son, lead steps around follow in clockwise direction
Stomp on 5 count towards center of circle
Partner exchange: take the next follower in the circle.
Skip one follower and take the second one.
Lead spins follow in a right turn, releases hand. "show it off."
Alternating display turns for leader and follower. Enchufla -> Leader goes under left arm, swapping positions with follow -> another enchufla -> dile que no
Simple partner pass across to the next leader.
Lead switches hands, right hand turn followed by arm-over-head pattern resembling placing a hat.
Sombrero followed by mambo-style footwork.
Named figure involving wrap-and-release patterns.
Sombrero variant where arms are "hooked" behind.
Enchufla finished with arms held like "penguin wings." for next 8 count as you switch to next partner
Pose-like ending where dancers "freeze" briefly.
Enchufla followed by the leader waving his right hand across the follow from left to right as she leans back under his arm.  Lean back goes for 8 counts.
Enchufla with added mambo footwork as you switch partner.
Dame followed by partner exchange in opposite direction, so go back to follower on the lead's left, then cross them back into guapea
Circular arm-loop pattern resembling a lasso. Enchufla then lead goes under their left arm, still facing forward, and leads the follow back around into dile que no.

Switch hands, using right hand bring the follow in front of leader.  Leader backsteps to the left and takes the follows left hand with their left, switching sides as the follow pivots on the 3 and 7.  Afer 3 full 8 counts, end in dile que no.

Enchufla and switch hands with leader ending up in front of follow in shadow position.  Leader backsteps with follow on opposite side for two 8 counts, then raises right arm for follow to end up ready for sombrero, dile que no to finish
Often comes from paso de son, lead crosses (front) on 3 and 7.  The follow pivots on the 3 and 7.  One the 1-2-3, they're walking towards center of circle, walking back on 5-6-7.
Lead uses left hand to lead follow in a right turn
Using left hand, lead follow in a right turn, using right hand on her shoulder on the 3 count, then she unwraps on the 5-6-7
Using left hand, lead follow in a right turn, using right hand on her shoulder on the 3 count, then lead her in a left turn on the unwrap with left hand, into a coca cola.
Leader changes hands, leads follow in a right turn, then hooks left arm with follows right arm and rotates around for another 8 count, into dile que no to finish
One of the most iconic long Rueda figures with complex wraps/turns.
Dame dos but with two claps as you're rotating
Right turn the follow into closed/arriba position
In closed position, raise followers right arm, lead travels forward under her arm to next follow
Closed position, walk forwards, anti-clockwise around the circle.
Enchufla followed by leader performing a right turn and switching hands, into a single-handed dile que no.
Closed position, walk backwards, clockwise around the circle.
Partner change move used with Hermana and Familia in rueda combinations.
Often paired with Prima; another partner change figure in rueda combos.
Combination pattern where Prima, Hermana and Familia are danced in sequence.
Playful follow-change variant often added after Familia combinations.
Named rueda figure with elevated or stacked arm pathways (varies by school).
Lead passes follower directly through with a simple forward motion. Lead switches to follower on their left
Arm loop (Lazo) pattern accented with claps, vocal calls, or playful styling.
Clap hands on 1 count.
Clap hands on 1-2 counts.
Clap hands on 1-2-3 counts.
Enchufla where the follower is led toward the center of the rueda circle. Directional calls such as Izquierda or Derecha may be added while in the center.
Directional call given while in Enchufla el Centro; leader rotates to the left before exiting.
Directional call given while in Enchufla el Centro; leader rotates to the right before exiting.
